content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The puzzle is informative and interesting. The statement obfuscates its difficulty, testing the clasher's capacity to identify the necessary information. The examples are clear and the tests block the naive loop solution (at least in Python). Well done!
i think you should explain how the calculations were done

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Looks good!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It is fun and wonderful contribution.

Wonderful puzzle. It is nice to peak into the mathematics of a particular industry and get a taste of it. Plus it seems a bit of a statement on the millions of years it takes radioactive material to decay. It is a lot to take in, especially under time constraints of a clash, but the fundamentals are pretty straight forward, save the exponential to get from number of half-lives to mass divisor. I like it.

Suggestions:

Statement
* 5Sv looks like 55v. Add a space (5 Sv) to make it easier to read in the risk ranges. Plus consistency with format used above.

Input
* Include the possible types in the Line 1 text (Plutonium-239, etc.).

Output
* Note that the number of years is to be rounded down.

"type" is a key word in python, not the best variable name, maybe put "t".
In the input section it would be more clear to put:
Line 3 : an integer h as the number of half-lives that have passed since disposal.
and in oputput:
A single line containing the number of years y that have passed since disposal ....
For the type it would be more accurate to put the full name "Plutonium-239" in the input since a same element can have many isotopes with various half-lives. It doesn't change the difficulty of the puzzle.
"Don't go in there" should be before "Let's take our time" because optimization tests should always be at the end.
For the "Cautious" test, the test is easier than the validator. Make sure you timeout the test if you do new_mass=m/2**h. 
otherwise the puzzle is fun and interesting. Good job!
I changed the exercise a bit to give it multiple solutions possible

Very interesting challenge.

Without the formula to calculate the half-life, the resolution of the challenge might be very difficult. Would you please consider adding it to the statement?

Input section
* Please format the line numbers as bold too, following the example in the contribution guidelines:
https://www.codingame.com/playgrounds/40701/help-center/statement#guidelines
* The description to line 3 is incomplete.

Output section
* You may remove the quotation marks and use {{constant}} formatting instead.

Cases
* Many of the cases are the same. I guess you're still working on them?

Thanks.

Great, thanks for the advice.
And yeah I'm still working on the test cases

Goal section: The description of Deadly is not formatted as bold properly. Please fix the syntax.

Thanks.
